titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Office Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Office Files FA1551

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-10 00:04:20 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Economic Development and Administration, Office Files

physdesc.extent: 11 boxes (10 letter document containers and 1 legal document container)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as part of Accession 2019:012 (boxes 30255, 30256, 30358); 2019:028 (box 30254).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into two series:
The original order of the material was maintained.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard Processing by Katie Martin, October 2019. Originally the files in this collection were part of two larger accessions called "Program Strategy records." The material was unrelated to the majority of these accessions and was separated to create this discrete collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

In 1950, the Ford Foundation's Trustees planned out five areas of activity. One area, Program Area III, revolved around "activities designed to advance the economic well-being of people everywhere and to improve economic institutions for the better realization of democratic goals." To comply with the Trustee's recommendations, the Foundation created an advisory group composed of leading economists. They published their report in 1954 with recommendations to focus on four major problem areas in the field of economics: 1.) understanding the effects of private interests of businesses, government agencies, labor union, and other organizations on public welfare; 2.) maintaining economic growth and stability; 3.) improving private and public policy; 4.) improving international economic relations. The economists proposed the Foundation focus on funding research activities, development of personnel in the field, and educating the public on economic issues.

In the 1950s and '60s, the Ford Foundation followed the advisory group's recommendations by funding conferences, nonprofits, and universities in the studies of natural resources, manpower, economic development, international economic relations, and the improvement of business administration and performance. The Foundation also funded faculty and student fellowships in economic studies, research centers at universities, and provided grants to improve business education at the undergraduate and graduate level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the formative documents of the Ford Foundation's program in Economic Development and Administration, including the meeting materials and correspondence of the initial advisory group. The collection also holds memos, reports, grant proposals, fellowship files, and budget information pertaining to initiatives to improve education and research in the fields of business and economics. The collection spans from 1950-1967.

did.unittitle: General Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents related to the development of the Ford Foundation's Economic Development and Administration program. This includes correspondence and meeting materials from the advisory group commissioned to shape the program, Foundation staff files (Kermit Gordon, Oscar Harkavy, Neil Chamberlain, Martin Shubik, Marshall Robinson), reports and surveys related to graduate studies in business and economics, and reports related to research centers at universities and the role of computers in economics education.

Public Administration
Fellowship Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In a 1954 report, an advisory group of leading economists and business administrators recommended the Ford Foundation fund fellowships in economics and administration to develop strong personnel in the field. The first fellowships were awarded in 1956.

This series includes memos, grant action forms, fellowship terms, press materials, application forms, form letters, survey materials, correspondence, spreadsheets, and lists of fellowship recipients. The types of fellowships awarded include: predoctoral fellowships, faculty research fellowships, faculty study fellowships, and doctoral dissertation fellowships in economics and business.
